The immediate benefit from the Project is increased productivity—
a yield response of approximately 100% is realistically achievable 
through  improved  water  management.  This  response  will  be 
expressed as increased household incomes for farmers with large 
areas  of  irrigated  land.  In  the  case  of  poor  households,  it  will 
mean  improved  food  security  through  the  dry  season,  thus 
reducing the extent of localized food deficits common throughout 
the  northwest  region.  The  greatest  benefit  will  come  from 
increased  cropping  options  with  a  more  secure  and  better-
managed  water  supply.  While  benefits  have  been  assessed 
primarily on the incremental paddy yields for both wet season and, 
where  possible,  dry  season  cropping,  more  diversified  cropping

further  gains  in  household  incomes.  The  average  incremental

yielding varieties of wet season rice and different vegetables. The

for  120,000  beneficiaries  in  about  15%  of  the  total  potential 
irrigation  command  area  for  the  four  project  provinces,  or  about 
40% of the total area currently under irrigation.

2. 
Cambodia  is  one  of  the  least  developed  countries  in  Asia  with  an  annual  per  capita 
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  of  $282  (2001),  a  gender  development  index  of  0.551  (2001), 
and a human development index of 0.556 (2001) resulting in a ranking of 130th in the lowest tier 
of the medium human development category.2 About 36% of Cambodia's population live below 
the  poverty  line.3  The  incidence  of  poverty  is  greater  in  rural  areas  (estimated  at  more  than 
40%)  where  about  90%  of  the  country’s  poor  are  found.  The  characteristics  of  poverty  differ 
across  the  country,  but  its  incidence,  however  defined,  is  higher  in  the  rural  areas  of  the 
northwest. 
 
3. 
Cambodia  is  predominantly  an  agrarian  society,  with  agriculture  accounting  for  39%  of 
GDP. At least 70% of the rural population directly depend on agriculture for  their livelihood. The 
sector has an important role to play in reducing rural poverty, meeting the expected population 
growth (2.4% per year), and improving nutritional requirements. Agricultural productivity remains 
low compared with that in other Southeast Asian countries with similar agro-climatic conditions. 
It is constrained by soil fertility, limited access to and thus use of farm inputs (particularly quality 
seed  material,  fertilizers  and  chemicals),  the  uncertainty  of  rainfall  and  frequent  occurrence of 
droughts  and  flooding,  the  inability  to  manage  extreme  water  flows,  and  a  weak  agricultural 
extension  service  that  limits  farmer  exposure  to  and  adoption  of  improved  production 
techniques. Furthermore, the poor rural road network results in high transport costs; restricted 
access  to  markets,  market  information,  and  credit;  and  generally  lower  farmgate  prices  for 
farmers  fortunate  enough  to  generate  surpluses  above  household  requirements.  Rice,  the 
staple  crop  of  Cambodia,  covers  about  90%  of  the  2.6  million  hectares  (ha)  cropped  area, 
contributing  46%  of  agricultural  output  and  providing  70%  of  nutritional  intake.  In  average  to 
good years, Cambodia is considered barely self-sufficient in rice, but this is only true nationally 
and sufficiency at provincial level varies considerably (in 2001, 13 out of 24 provinces reported a 
deficit).4  Many  rural  households,  especially  in  the  northwest  region,  continue  to  suffer  rice 
deficits for up to 6 months of the year.5 
 
4.

Mekong Basin and a gross water resource of nearly 50,000 cubic meters per person per year.

Competition for Water and a River Basin Perspective. Cambodia’s water sector legal 
and policy framework has provision for managing water resources in a river basin perspective, 
but this has not yet been implemented. Even though there has been little development of upper 
catchment resources, competition among water users has been an ongoing issue, especially in 
the  northwest.  In  addition,  competition  for  water  is  likely  to  increase  because  of  urban  areas, 
hydropower,  irrigation,  and  residual  stream  flow  requirements  to  maintain  ecosystems  and 
fisheries, especially in the Tonle Sap and Mekong River systems. Water resources planning and 
management  need  a  river  basin  development  perspective  to  ensure  that  water  is  used  to 
achieve the greatest net economic and social benefit, while preventing conflict and competition, 
creating  an  environment  conducive  to  satisfying  present  and  foreseeable  demands,  and 
sustaining environmental requirements. This is best done through the adoption of an integrated 
water resources management (IWRM)7 approach. The Government has promoted the principles 
of IWRM in a river  basin context, but needs further resourcing and institutional capacity building 
to operationalize the approach.

59. 
The concept of IWRM to river basin development is still new in Cambodia and there is 
a  risk  that  its  adoption  will  be  slow  and  not  as  comprehensive  as  desired.  Government 
commitment is clear in its current water sector legal and policy framework and key MOWRAM 
and  PDWRAMs  staff  have  already  been  exposed  to  the  concept,  in  both  theoretical  and 
practical ways during project preparation. The Project also has adequate provision for additional 
capacity building to ensure adoption and use of the approach. 
 
60. 
Slow  farmer  adoption  of  improved  techniques  of  irrigated  agricultural  production, 
water  management  practices,  and  production  diversification  has  the  potential  to  delay  the 
project  benefits.  The  subprojects  will  rehabilitate  existing  irrigation  schemes  where  a  resident 
knowledge  of  irrigated  agriculture  exists.  Also  with  improved  security  of  water  supplies,  risk 
management  will  be  less  an  issue  in  determining  cropping  activities  and  testing  improved 
methods  of  production.  In  addition,  extensive  investment  in  community  development  will  help 
farmers’  early  and  sustained  involvement  in  designing  and  implementing  on-farm  irrigation 
management and irrigated agricultural extension, and in the continuing development of end-user 
ownership. Furthermore, the Project will  work  closely  with  programs  already  operating  in  the 
subproject areas and agencies that have already accumulated considerable experience in rice 
farming systems.38 
 
61.

participation  in  O&M  and  management  of  the  schemes  to  ensure  the  sustainability  of 
investments  and  to  reduce  the  financial  burden  on  the  Government.  The  Project  directs

SECTOR/SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
 

Agriculture  accounts  for  39%  of  Cambodia’s  gross  domestic  product  and  is  the  main 
1. 
source of livelihood of 70% of the rural population. Agricultural productivity is low compared with 
that in other Southeast Asian countries with similar agroclimatic conditions because of, among 
others,  the  highly  variable  rainfall,  limited  irrigation  development,  and  poor  performance  of 
existing  irrigation  facilities.  Rice  is  the  predominant  crop  (90%  of  the  2.6  million  hectares  [ha] 
cropped  area)  accounting  for  46%  of  the  economic  value  added  in  agriculture  and  providing 
about  70%  of  the  average  nutritional  intake  (estimated  at  151  kilograms  of  rice1). Wet season 
rice–(yielding 3.2 million tons, or about 80% of total rice production) is grown between May and 
September  on  the  extensive  central  floodplains  of  the  Mekong  River  and  the  lowlands  around 
the Tonle Sap under rain-fed conditions and consists predominantly of local varieties preferred 
for  domestic  consumption.  Because  of  the  flat  terrain  and  poor  drainage,  flooding  is  common 
and  wet  season  planting  begins  either  on  well-drained  areas  or  after  the  rainy  season  due  to 
localized  inundation.  Dry  season  rice  (0.8  million  tons),  consisting  of  high-yielding varieties, is 
grown between December and March. It is the higher yielding and more profitable crop, most of 
which  is  marketed.  In  2000,  the  average  rice  yield  was  3.2  and  1.9  tons/hectare (t/ha) for dry 
and  wet  season  crops,  respectively—well  below  levels  achieved  in  neighboring  countries.  In 
average to good years, Cambodia is considered barely self-sufficient in rice, but this is only true 
nationally; sufficiency at the provincial level varies considerably (in 2001, 13 out of 24 provinces 
reported deficits).2 Due to the limited rural road networks (resulting in high transport costs and 
restricted  access  to  markets)  and  localized  droughts  and  flooding,  many  rural  households, 
especially in the northwest region, continue to suffer rice deficits for up to 6 months of the year.3

In 1999, the Government established the Ministry of Water Resources and Meteorology

the  General  Directorate  of  Irrigation,  Meteorology  and  Hydrology  under  the  Ministry  of 
Agriculture,  Forestry  and  Fisheries  (MAFF).  MOWRAM  is  responsible  for  defining  water 
resources  management  policies  and  strategies,  collecting  and  analyzing  data,  planning  water 
resource use, regulating water use activities that have a negative impact on the resource, and 
mitigating  the  impact  of  water-related  natural  disasters  such  as  floods  and  droughts.  The 
previous directorate focused mainly on irrigation, hydrology, and meteorology, while MOWRAM 
now has the broader responsibilities of developing and managing water resources.

that  water  resources  management  and  irrigation  development  are  part  of  the  priority  actions

11.  With the assistance of ADB7 and the World Bank, 8 MOWRAM has achieved significant 
progress  toward  establishing  a  legal  and  policy  framework  for  the  water  sector,  including  the 
irrigation  subsector,  and  in  developing  a  vision  for  national  water  resources  and  an  effective 
strategic  approach  to  their  development  and  management.  Several  major  steps  have  been 
taken in recent years and significant documents have been developed, including (i) a National 
Water Sector Profile (2001) that reviews and analyzes the existing situation in the water sector, 
together with a short- and long-term development perspective of the sector; (ii) a  draft Law on 
Water  Resources  Management  (2001)  and  supporting  implementation  subdecrees  to  regulate 
the water sector management that has passed the Council of Ministers and has been submitted 
to the National Assembly for promulgation; (iii) a  draft  National Water Resources Policy (2001) 
to  provide  a  basis  for  managing  the  country’s  overall  water  resources  and  for  developing 
subsectoral  policies  and  strategies  that  has  been  submitted  to  the  Council  of  Ministers  for 
deliberation; (iv) a draft National Water Resources Strategy (2001) that gives an extensive list of 
proposed objectives, strategies, and actions in all areas of the water sector for incorporation in 
the  NPRS;  (v)  a  Strategic  Framework  for  the  Water  Sector  (2001)  based  on  the  agenda  for 
actions included in the National Water Sector Profile, and a number of MOWRAM strategic and 
investment  plans  to  effect  it;  and  (vi)  an  Investment  Strategy  for  the  Water  Resources Sector 
that is in its early stage of preparation.

SUMMARY ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSES 

Appendix 13 

49 

The  overall  purpose  of  the  Project  is  to  improve  water  resource management through 
1. 
institutional  strengthening,  infrastructure  development,  and  agricultural  support  using  a  sector 
approach.  The  purpose  will  be  achieved  through  the  rehabilitation  of  small  to  medium-scale 
irrigation schemes servicing a potential command area of 35,000 hectares (ha)—19,000 ha for 
flood spreading and/or recession cropping, 16,000 ha for wet season irrigated cropping, 5,000 
ha  for  dry  season  irrigated  cropping—directly  affecting  some  24,000  families  or  an  estimated 
120,000 beneficiaries. As a result of (i) improved water management during the wet season, (ii) 
use of seasonal surpluses for flood spreading and/or recession practices for better management 
of  localized  flooding,  and  (iii)  greater  retention  of  surface  runoff  in  the  upper  reaches  of 
catchments  (without  having  detrimental  impacts  on  downstream  users),  coupled  with  adoption 
of improved production technologies, the Project will improve food security in rice-deficit areas 
of  the  northwest.  Improved  water  security  will  also  raise  household  incomes  where  market 
access exists by permitting diversification into high–value/high–yielding rice and crops of higher 
value.  Economic  and  financial  analyses  were  prepared  for  three  representative  core 
subprojects, two typifying rice-insecure situations and the other, Po Pi Deum, where the better 
urban market access justifies the production of perishable, higher-value goods. 
 
2. 
The analysis attempts to quantify measurable benefits based on incremental production 
of rice (primarily), the traditional crop in the area with some diversification represented by mung 
beans  and  cucurbits.  Other  nonquantifiable  benefits  are  expected  depending  on  the  nature  of 
the  subproject.  Flood  management  can  give  protection  to  households;  embankments  that 
double as rural roads can allow better access to adjacent producing areas as well as improved 
access to social services (health and education, etc.); improved nutritional status of households 
in areas where food deficits are common, and improved access to domestic water sources that 
survive the dry season are all likely to be realized under the Project. Benefits from institutional 
strengthening initiatives are considered significant because government agencies will be able to 
better  plan  and  monitor  development  in  the  water  sector.  As  this  is  a  sector  project,  the 
economic  analysis  presented  here  and  in  Supplementary  Appendix  I  will  be  a  model  for 
assessing and selecting potential irrigation schemes to rehabilitate to achieve both food security 
and income generation through diversification. 
 
G. 

Methodology 

3. 
Financial prices used in the analysis were identified through a survey of the subproject 
area  and  cross-checked  with  prices  identified  in  other  projects  and  other  secondary  sources.

The  Po  Pi  Deum  subproject,  assessed  over  the  25-year  life  of  the  investment,  is

assuming  a  12%  opportunity  cost  of  capital.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  is

14. 
Investment  Cost.  While  care  was  taken  to  accurately  estimate  the  cost  of  the 
subproject  investment  (that  has  been  revised  upward  since  the  feasibility  design  study),  it  is 
possible that actual costs may be higher than the estimate. A 20% increase in investment costs 
will cause the EIRR to fall to 15.4%. The sensitivity factor is 0.7 and the switching value occurs 
at a 59% increase in investment cost. 
 
15.

suffer  from  poor  quality  of  construction  and/or  inadequate  maintenance,  the  latter  being  a 
function  of  both  local  perceptions  and  limited  budgetary  allocations.  It  was  assumed  that,  with 
proper O&M, the Po Pi Deum subproject will last for 25 years. If the project life actually turns out

maintenance, the EIRR will decrease to 17.4%. The switching value of project life (shorter than 
which the Project will have an EIRR below 12%) is 15 years less than that assumed in the base 
case.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Cambodia: 90% of the poor in Cambodia are found in rural 
areas. Nearly 70% of rural households (HHs) depend on agriculture for their livelihood. A strong link exists between 
the incidence of poverty and agricultural productivity among the large numbers of small-scale subsistence producers 
where food deficits of greater than 6 months each year are common. Food insecurity is an important indicator of 
poverty and communities themselves classify food-insecure HHs as poor. Water resources are a key factor in 
promoting agricultural productivity to improve food security, income generation, job creation, and the general quality 
of life in rural areas. Through the development of the water resources sector, the Project will improve the agriculture 
sector, which contributes 39% of the gross domestic product (GDP), and employs 70% of the labor force. 

Poverty Analysis   

 

 

Proposed Classification:   

Poverty Intervention 

With political stability returning to the northwest as late as 1998, the region has been left out of many development 
initiatives (largely aid-funded) until the past decade. In terms of overall poverty incidence, Siem Reap Province ranks 
second  among  the  24  provinces  while  Banteay  Meanchey  and  Pursat  rank  7th  and  8th,  respectively.  Battambang 
Province’s  ranking  (14th)  is  skewed  by  the  large  urban  population  in  Battambang  township  that  masks  the 
widespread  poverty  in  the  southern  rural  districts  of  that  province.  Based  on  surveys  in  the  core  subproject  areas 
during project preparation, 60% of HHs live below the poverty line1 and 60% suffer food deficits as early as 4 months 
after  the  annual  harvest.  With  increasing  deforestation  in  the  area,  the  option  of  foraging,  hunting,  and  collecting 
forest  products  is  rapidly  declining  so  that  coping  mechanisms  have  become  less  secure.  Health  and  education 
indicators are very poor, with 11,000 people per health center and less than 20% of inhabitants completing primary 
education. Literacy rates of 46.2% are overstated as it includes those who are only partially literate. Only 1.25% of 
the rural population have access to safe drinking water  and sanitation. Most rely on hand-dug wells and streams that 
become  fouled  during  the  long  dry  season  and  experience  a  high  incidence  of  waterborne  diseases  and  parasitic 
infections.  Competition  for  the  better  agricultural  land  has  intensified  with  the  increased political stability and mine 
clearance activities, and the extent of landless HHs is estimated at 20%, even though they may still sharecrop on 
others’ land. 

The poor HHs are characterized by having smaller plots of land (0.2-0.5 hectare (ha) compared with an average of 
1.3 ha) or no land at all, mostly in rain-fed areas. Where irrigation exists, their plots are usually found on the outer 
extremities  of  schemes  where  the  delivery  of  water  is  unreliable.  Poor  HHs  plant  traditional  varieties  with  minimal 
inputs  of  animal  dung,  achieve  well  below  average  yields  from  their  smallholdings,  and  have  no  access  to  credit. 
They  live  in  areas  with  limited  access  to  markets  because  of  poor  rural  roads  and  have  limited  employment 
opportunities  other  than  in  neighboring  farmers’  fields.  What  little  land  they  have  tends  to  be  poorly  drained  and 
prone to annual flooding. They live in houses made of natural materials collected from forest areas, in conditions that 
are unhygienic, undermining health and income-earning opportunities. In most cases, physical and social exclusion 
compound the other, resulting in a perpetual poverty cycle of poor access to basic infrastructure and services, poor 
health,  poor  living  conditions,  low  productivity,  and  hence  low  incomes.  Some  groups  are  more  prone  to 
poverty- HHs headed by women and HHs with elderly and disabled family members where excessive workloads are 
imposed  on  the  remaining  HH  members  and  traditional  gender-related  activities  such  as  water  collection  are 
reallocated. 

Project  Strategies  for  Poverty  Reduction.  While  the  Project  is  constrained  by  the  availability  of  water  in 
undertaking  irrigation  rehabilitation,  the  selection  criteria  adopted  during  project  design  and  during  implementation 
will  ensure  that  priority  is  accorded  to  schemes  with  the  greatest  potential  to  contribute  to  poverty  reduction.  The 
development  of  irrigation  water  resources  will  have  a  direct  impact  on  poverty  reduction  through  increased 
employment opportunities as well as other social benefits. The Project will enable the poor to participate equitably in 
project activities and benefit from them. Communities to be included in all subprojects will enter into agreements with 
the Project to construct through community effort tertiary and quaternary canals, which will improve access to water 
for landholdings of the marginal farmers located at distances from the canal. Such agreements will be monitored by 
the  Project  and  will  form  part  of  the  basis  for  the  Project  undertaking  construction  and  rehabilitation  works  for 
irrigation improvements. All water user groups will include representatives of marginal farmer HHs as well as landless 
HHs living and working in the area. The Project will deploy irrigation extension workers (IEWs) who will work with the 
farmer water  user groups, and will provide training and facilitation services in forming groups and decision making, in 
agriculture  extension,  and  in  diversification  of  income-generating  activities  (off-farm livelihoods activities including 
livestock  rearing  and  fisheries).  The  IEWs  will  facilitate  the  participation  of  the  poor  HHs,  particularly  the  landless 
HHs,  in  the  water  user  groups  to  improve  their  capacity  to  benefit  from  livelihood  opportunities,  i.e.,  by  improving 
their  access  to  water  for  health  and  hygiene,  or  their  access  to  microfinance  for  productive  activities  through

C. 

Participation Process 

Initial Stakeholder Analysis. During project preparation, a participatory approach was adopted in carrying out the 
social  investigations  using  focus  group  discussions  and  participatory  rural  appraisals  within  the  rural  communities 
including  women  and  disadvantaged  groups,  and  in  identifying  potential  subprojects  with  a  wider  group  of 
stakeholders  including  provincial  and  district  administrations.  During  processing,  stakeholder  participation  ensured 
that local government staff were aware of the poverty objectives of the Project and used those criteria in selecting 
eligible subprojects to be considered for financing. 

Project  Participation  Strategy.  The  strategy  for  participation  during  subproject  implementation  will  begin  at  the 
feasibility  study  stage  with  beneficiary  information  and  awareness  campaigns,  and  early  identification  of  any 
resettlement requirements. Greater beneficiary participation will be required during the detailed design stage in (i) 
determining canal alignments; (ii) initiating the land adjustment and consolidation process that will eventually lead to 
the development of a landholding registry to be used in the subsequent issue of cadastral titles; and (iii) initiating the 
process  of  establishing  farmer  water  user  communities  (FWUCs)  and  subordinate water user groups (WUGs). To 
assist  in  this  participatory  process,  the  Project  will  fund  irrigation  extension  teams  (IETs)  to  be  recruited  through 
suitably  experienced  mass  organizations  and  comprising  a  social/community  development  specialist,  an  irrigation 
management  specialist  and,  later,  an  agricultural  extension  specialist.  Once  the  scheme  is  rehabilitated,  the 
participation  of  beneficiaries  will  continue  with  the  IETs  training  and  strengthening  the  FWUCs  in  view  of  the 
progressive transfer of irrigation management transfer and scheme ownership. This overall participatory process will 
require  extensive  support  from  the  IETs  to  identify  and  assist  disadvantaged  and  vulnerable  groups  within  the 
FWUCs  and  WUGs  and  in  training  them  in  gender  awareness,  group  management,  etc.  The  sustainability  of  the 
project intervention will depend on the successful participation of the beneficiaries. 

 
D. 

Gender and Development 

Project Gender Strategies.  Gender is closely linked with poverty in Cambodia. Rural women in general lack access 
to agricultural training and extension. They are also disadvantaged by the lack of clean drinking water supplies, and 
clean  water  for  personal  hygiene.  Women  bear  the  responsibility  for  domestic  work  and  health  care  for  sick  family 
members. Their participation in community decision making is low. The lack of gender sensitivity among providers of 
agricultural training and extension further exacerbates the problem. Although women provide a significant amount of 
labor in agriculture, they are hardly targeted in official training and extension programs, have limited representation in 
local committees and, consequently, lower access to information. HHs headed by females (about 15% of the HHs in 
the  studied  core  subproject  areas),  especially  in  the  northwest,  tend  to  be  poorer  on  account  of  high  dependency 
levels, lack of adequate adult labor (in particular male labor for income generation), heavy work burdens, low levels 
of  education  of  female  household  heads  (5–10%  lower  literacy  rates  in  the studied subproject areas), low health 
levels,  low  level  of  access  to  land,  and  lack  of  capacity  to  undertake  cultivation  on  account  of  lack  of  capital  and 
inputs (although they are often considered as lower credit risks) among other factors.  
The  Project  will  adopt  gender  strategies  to  reach  out  to  poor  women  through  improved  access  to  services,  inputs, 
training, and capital. Women beneficiaries will be helped to join WUGs and participate in all group activities. Of the 
IEWs  deployed  by  the  Project  at  field  level,  30%  will  be  women  and  will  be  particularly  responsible  for  facilitating 
women’s empowerment (decision making) and participation in project activities. All group members will be trained in 
gender  issues  to  create  at  grassroots  level  the  capacity  to  improve  gender  relations  and  facilitate  equitable 
participation by the poor in project activities. Women farmers will be particularly targeted in all extension and training 
activities—including  seed  production,  inputs  supply—and  be  selected  as  key  farmers for demonstration activities. 
They will also be targeted for specific training in microfinance and livelihoods diversification. Women beneficiaries will 
be particularly involved in decision making related to the setting up of washing points and drinking water supply to 
benefit  them  by  reducing  their  drudgery  and  increasing  their  time  for  other  activities.  All  project  monitoring  and 
evaluation  will  be  gender  responsive.  Gender  impacts  will  be  measured  by  changes  in  women’s  access  to  water 
resources,  improved  crop  production,  improvements  in  income,  food  security,  other  livelihood  opportunities, 
participation in training, access to decision making in the groups, changes in the gender division of labor, and overall
